user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of find_auth_rq_header_:
```c
static bool
find_auth_rq_header_ (const struct MHD_Connection *c, enum MHD_AuthType type,
                      struct _MHD_str_w_len *auth_value)
{
  const struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *h;
  const char *token;
  size_t token_len;

  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED <= c->state);
  if (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED > c->state)
    return false;

#ifdef DAUTH_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_AUTHTYPE_DIGEST == type)
  {
    token = _MHD_AUTH_DIGEST_BASE;
    token_len = MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (_MHD_AUTH_DIGEST_BASE);
  }
  else /* combined with the next line */
#endif /* DAUTH_SUPPORT */
#ifdef BAUTH_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_AUTHTYPE_BASIC == type)
  {
    token = _MHD_AUTH_BASIC_BASE;
    token_len = MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (_MHD_AUTH_BASIC_BASE);
  }
  else /* combined with the next line */
#endif /* BAUTH_SUPPORT */
  {
    mhd_assert (0);
    return false;
  }

  for (h = c->rq.headers_received; NULL != h; h = h->next)
  {
    if (MHD_HEADER_KIND != h->kind)
      continue;
    if (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (MHD_HTTP_HEADER_AUTHORIZATION) != h->header_size)
      continue;
    if (token_len > h->value_size)
      continue;
    if (! MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (MHD_HTTP_HEADER_AUTHORIZATION,
                                         h->header,
                                         MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                           MHD_HTTP_HEADER_AUTHORIZATION)))
      continue;
    if (! MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (h->value, token, token_len))
      continue;
    /* Match only if token string is full header value or token is
     * followed by space or tab
     * Note: RFC 9110 (and RFC 7234) allows only space character, but
     * tab is supported here as well for additional flexibility and uniformity
     * as tabs are supported as separators between parameters.
     */
    if ((token_len == h->value_size) ||
        (' ' == h->value[token_len]) || ('\t'  == h->value[token_len]))
    {
      if (token_len != h->value_size)
      { /* Skip whitespace */
        auth_value->str = h->value + token_len + 1;
        auth_value->len = h->value_size - (token_len + 1);
      }
      else
      { /* No whitespace to skip */
        auth_value->str = h->value + token_len;
        auth_value->len = h->value_size - token_len;
      }
      return true; /* Found a match */
    }
  }
  return false; /* No matching header has been found */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED > c->state)
    return false;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated: the controlling expression (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED > c->state) depends on the runtime value c->state, so it is not an invariant compile-time constant. MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED is a constant but c->state is a variable parameter, therefore the if-condition can be true or false at runtime. Note: a static analyser that treats the preceding mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED <= c->state) as a guaranteed contract (i.e. an assumption that cannot fail) might consider the if-condition always false and thus report a violation — that would be a false-positive based on how mhd_assert is interpreted or compiled out.
